For me, the short version of the story is this:

When many test methods have common set-up code, I refactor to
TestCase.setUp. This forms a "fixture": a common set of data for the
tests in the TestCase.

When my TestCase contains some set-up code that these tests use and
some different set-up code that those tests use, I really want to
separate the fixtures into two TestCases. Maybe I even want to separate
the behavior under test into separate classes, but that's not always
clear. By living with a TestCase that has multiple bits of orthogonal
setUp code, I miss an opportunity to learn about my design.

Thus, a TestCase is a fixture: common setUp for a number of tests --
tests associated with a certain bit of behavior that may or may not be
implemented in its own class.

Does that give you an idea?
